content:
Hello there kraher99. We have read your message . We try to help you.

You can automatically forward the messages you still receive via Thunderbird filters if you have the time. there are abc xyz tools that try to fix certain things, yes.

But those emails that are probably already lurking on your computer network or nesting in your PC are unpleasantly plain Spam.

First try your PCs or network with which you work, also server. First, do a thorough cleaning of these Spams.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages


Feel free to create an anti-Spam folder with your employees to have them refer the relevant news letter mails or company mails to this anti-spam folder. This saves your inbox.

And clean up your internally /external-backup devices to. Or before you use them

There is also Anti Spam Sofware available. Greetings Firefox volunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Hello there kraher99


as for stopping Thunderbird from synchronizing it is not possible it keeps updating and synchronizing folders. The reason is that it does indeed want to use Imap.

You will continue to see the supply of folders continuously just like on a smart phone with our app you are using today in 2023.

It is recommended that deleting this account actually stop it. When you need this account again, you can install it again. When re-creating an account with us, it will indeed be the same again at a time.


tell the colleagues you work with to look at initial setup. I can send you some previews


Initial setup.

Check that your antivirus software isn't configured to delete your Inbox if you get a virus. If you AV doesn't support quarantining infected messages, see this article for a workaround for pop inboxes.

Don't check for viruses in messages you send. This avoids interoperability problems. And if the recipient isn't already using a anti-virus program, then they have bigger problems to worry about than your potentially infected message.

Don't keep a copy of your messages on the POP server without providing some way to automatically get rid of them later. If you use "Tools -> Account Settings -> Server Settings -> Leave message on server" to keep a copy of the original message on the POP server after Thunderbird checks for new mail (so that you can still access it via webmail), then you should set the number of days it should keep the copy.


Greetings Firefox volunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

creator: kraher99

content:
The Imap account should have been up and running within minutes.

Everytime you select a folder, it will synch with server to update. Emails get downloaded initially and then only new mail gets auto downloaded. However, that depends upon whether you are synchronising emails - downloading full copies or whether you only downloaded headers in which case each email is downloaded from server when you select to view it.

You should not be repeatedly trying to download same emails. Have you subscribed to see all the folders or where you just downloading to a couple of them at a time before subscribing to see more of them?

The message in last image says 'downloading message 9 of 4 ATB Banking' Agree that is weird. How many emails are currently in the imap ATB Banking folder? In webmail account - ATB Banking (sounds like a folder) - how many emails are in that folder?

Have you created ANY Message Filters in Thunderbird? Advise you do not create any Message Filters at this point in time.


re :My inbox has many "blank" messages. It is possible the index file is out of synch with whatever has been downloaded to Inbox folder. The following does not effect what has been downloaded but it does force the index file to recheck the Inbox.

See if the following fixes this:

  • Right click on 'Inbox' and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Repair folder'
  • Click on OK'



In Account Settings > Server Settings Is this selected : 'check for new messages at start up' ? Is this selected : 'check for new messages every XX minutes' ? How frequently is it checking - suggest you use 15 minutes or more. Again it may be just as easy to post an image showing all on that page.


Imap accounts can download full copies of emails or just headers and that can be done on a per folder basis. In Account Settings > Synchronisation & Storage What have you got set up? Is this selected : 'Keep messages in all folders for this account on this computer' ? Click on 'Advanced..' button Is every folder and subfolder selected or are some selected and others not selected? What do you see?

What is selected under 'Disk Space' ?

It may be quicker to post info if you uploaded some images.


Anti-Virus Advise given regarding Anti-Virus software was good advise. You do not want any Anti-Virus messing about with any of the emails that get downloaded nor any of the files that store emails. Do not scan incoming or outgoing mail and do not allow Anti-Virus to auto fix anything. In addition I suggest you do not allow it to scan any Thunderbird profile folder or it's contents as it can play havoc with files that store emails.

Firewall - Thunderbird program should be set up as an allowed program otherwise it can be awkward about allowing access to internet.

Advise you never only rely on whatever is held on server because it is only one copy. Any imap account can also effect what is on server because they are in effect one and the same.

content:
First image showing server settings 'Authentication Method': you have selected 'Encypted Password' Are you certain that is the advised option to select. Are you using an encrypted password? Usually people select 'Normal Password' because they are using a normal password.

re last image on Synchronisation.

The option 'Keep messages in all folders...... is selected - that means all the folders in the 'Advanced..' button window would normally be auto selected.

But you unchecked all those folders, then it will not download full copies of any emails.

You have selected 'Synchronise the most recent 30 days' This means for all the folders you selected in the 'Advanced..' area, only the most recent 30 days will get fully downloaded, all other emails in those selected folders will only download headers. Any folder not selected will not synchronise any emails, so only downloads headers.

However, no folders are selected then no emails will be synchronised - all emails will only download headers. So it renders that Synchronise option useless.

You have also blocked the download of any email that is larger than 50KB. But many seem to have attachments. Have you checked the size of the emails you have on the server/webmail ? Has this setting had any effect on emails - are any of the emails on the server larger than 50KB ?

If you do not want any emails to be fully downloaded - you only want headers then: Uncheck 'Keep messages in all folders.....' Uncheck any folder in that 'Advanced..' button area

If you want to download full copies of all emails in all folders. (I would try going with this option to keep it simple and do not put a limit on size) Select : 'Keep messages in all folders..... it should auto select all the folders in the 'Advanced' area.

If you want to download full copies for specific folders, but not for others Select : 'Keep messages in all folders..... Click on 'Advanced..' Only select the folders you want to synchronise - full download messages.

If in addition to the you want to only fully synchronise a limited number of emails in those selected folders, then the option 'Synchronise the most recent 30 days' would be applied to all the folders you selected.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Enable hardware acceleration in Settings/General, restart TB, and see if it helps. Acceleration is disabled in TB safe mode, and in most cases it should be disabled in normal mode. But there are rare cases where it should be enabled.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thank you for the though but, though I can open the Account Settings when I attempt to open Thunderbird Settings nothing happens so I see no way of Enabling hardware acceleration. Please note that when I open Account Settings both of my accounts are listed with the correct server information and the "More Troubleshooting Information" page lists both accounts as well as my calendar settings.
creator: eagerdas

content:
If you can't open Settings, there is a way to enable acceleration by closing TB, opening prefs.js in the profile folder with a text editor, and adding this line:

user_pref("gfx.direct2d.disabled", false);

If the pref. is already there, with the value true, it means acceleration is disabled in normal mode.

content:
Hello there hfjabre. We have read your message. We try to help you.


What calendar are you using? Do you use multiple calendars in Thunderbird? Deleting all your entries.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/calendar-updates-issues-thunderbird

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/changing-calendar-

to delete the items saved from your calendar that you might have saved in a backup, also delete them from your computer.(Thunderbird map). you can delete and reinstall the entire program.

To cleanup manually, rightclick on any calendar and choose "purge Events...". Select the Calendar from the list, set the time you want to keep and press 'cleanup now'. To enable/disable autopurge use the setting, set the settings for each calendar and apply separately.


Greetings Firefox volunteer.

content: Did you upgrade directly from 38 to 102? That may be part of your problem, as Thunderbird does 'housekeeping' at the beginning of each series. The generally recommended upgrade path is to go via first release of each series, e.g., 45.0.1, 52.0.1, etc., up to 102.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you for the suggestion. Let me see if I understand this correctly. In order for passwords to work in Thunderbird, I should uninstall the version I have, then research how many "series" there are, then download these old versions, then upgrade progressively to the latest version. And maybe this will work? Note that I have already upgraded, so there is no way to tell what remains of the original versions or what files are causing the problem (I already deleted all the common culprits that are recommended to eliminate). I realize this is an open source software, built on the backs of volunteers, but this method seems like a sure-fire way to eliminate old users. There must be a simpler way to use passwords.

Any other suggestions?

I agree it is cumbersome, and only works if you still have the original profile. Over the years, Thunderbird makes changes and has code in place during the early stages of a release. By not keeping up, you can end up with a cumbersome upgrade approach. Depending on how many accounts you have, installing fresh might be a good option. But there are some excellent technical experts on this forum and if one of them sees this thread, they may have other options.

If you have a secmod.db in the profile, delete it, as it sometimes blocks normal password operations.

https://support.mozilla.org/nl/questions/1373145
creator: sfhowes

content: Solved! Delete secmod.db from Thunderbird files, and now a master password can be entered, and it remains. All else follows. Thank you sfhowes...).
